It is classified as a [[paraphilia]] by the [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual]] of the [[American Psychiatric Association]]. The word is artificially derived from the ancient Greek words: ''[[wikt:Î½ÎµÎºÏÏÏ|Î½ÎµÎºÏÏÏ]]'' (''nekros''; "dead") and ''[[wikt:ÏÎ¹Î»Î¯Î±|ÏÎ¹Î»Î¯Î±]]'' (''philia''; "love"). The term appears to have originated from [[Richard Freiherr von Krafft-Ebing|Krafft-Ebing]]'s 1886 work ''[[Psychopathia Sexualis (book)|Psychopathia Sexualis]]''.<ref>Krafft-Ebing, Richard von (1886). '''Necrophilia''', also called '''thanatophilia''', and '''necrolagnia''', is the [[human sexuality|sexual]] attraction to [[Cadaver|corpses]]. It is classified as a [[paraphilia]] by the [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual]] of the [[American Psychiatric Association]]. The word is artificially derived from the ancient Greek words: ''[[wikt:Î½ÎµÎºÏÏÏ|Î½ÎµÎºÏÏÏ]]'' (''nekros''; "dead") and ''[[wikt:ÏÎ¹Î»Î¯Î±|ÏÎ¹Î»Î¯Î±]]'' (''philia''; "love"). The term appears to have originated from [[Richard Freiherr von Krafft-Ebing|Krafft-Ebing]]'s 1886 work ''[[Psychopathia Sexualis (book)|Psychopathia Sexualis]]''.<ref>Krafft-Ebing, Richard von (1886). ''Psychopathia Sexualis''. English translation: ISBN 1-55970-425-X.</ref>
â
Rosman and Resnick (1989) reviewed information from 34 cases of necrophilia describing the individuals' motivations for their behaviors: these individuals reported the desire to possess an unresisting and unrejecting partner (68%), reunions with a romantic partner (21%), sexual attraction to corpses (15%), comfort or overcoming feelings of isolation (15%), or seeking self-esteem by expressing power over a homicide victim (12%).<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Rosman | first1 = J. P. | last2 = Resnick | first2 = P. J. | year = 1989 | title = Sexual attraction to corpses: A psychiatric review of necrophilia | url = | journal = Bulletin of the American Academy of Psychiatry and the Law | volume = 17 | issue = | pages = 153â163 }}</ref><!---WHAT are the demographics? Are all male or female? When and where are the stats being sampled from? Does it represent the worldwide view?--->
+
Rosman and Resnick (1989) reviewed information from 34 cases of necrophilia describing the individuals' motivations for their behaviors: these individuals reported the desire to possess an unresisting and unrejecting partner (68%), reunions with a romantic partner (21%), sexual attraction to corpses (15%), comfort or overcoming feelings of isolation (15%), or seeking self-esteem by expressing power over a homicide victim (12%).<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Rosman | first1 = J. P. | last2 = Resnick | first2 = P. J. | year = 1989 | title = Sexual attraction to corpses: A psychiatric review of necrophilia | url = | journal = Bulletin of the American Academy of Psychiatry and the Law | volume = 17 | issue = 2| pages = 153â163 | pmid = 2667656 }}</ref><!---WHAT are the demographics? Are all male or female? When and where are the stats being sampled from? Does it represent the worldwide view?--->
==History==
==History==
Line 32: Line 32:
In 1958, Klaf and Brown<ref name="klaf">Klaf, Franklin S., and Brown, William (1958). "Necrophilia: Brief Review and Case Report," ''the Psychoanalytic Quarterly'', 29(143), 645-652. "Inhibited forms of necrophilia and necrophilic fantasies may occur more commonly then is generally realized."</ref> commented that, although rarely described, necrophilic [[fantasy (psychology)|fantasies]] may occur more often than is generally supposed.
In 1958, Klaf and Brown<ref name="klaf">Klaf, Franklin S., and Brown, William (1958). "Necrophilia: Brief Review and Case Report," ''the Psychoanalytic Quarterly'', 29(143), 645-652. "Inhibited forms of necrophilia and necrophilic fantasies may occur more commonly then is generally realized."</ref> commented that, although rarely described, necrophilic [[fantasy (psychology)|fantasies]] may occur more often than is generally supposed.

Rosman and Resnick<ref name="rosman">{{cite journal | last1 = Rosman | first1 = Jonathan P. | last2 = Resnick | first2 = Phillip J. | year = 1989 | title = Sexual attraction to corpses: a psychiatric review of necrophilia | url = http://www.burknet.com/robsfantasy/section11a.html | journal = Bulletin of the American Academy of Psychiatry and the Law | volume = 17 | issue = | pages = 153â163 }}</ref> (1989) theorized that either of the following situations could be antecedents to necrophilia (pp. 161):
+
Rosman and Resnick<ref name="rosman">{{cite journal | last1 = Rosman | first1 = Jonathan P. | last2 = Resnick | first2 = Phillip J. | year = 1989 | title = Sexual attraction to corpses: a psychiatric review of necrophilia | url = http://www.burknet.com/robsfantasy/section11a.html | journal = Bulletin of the American Academy of Psychiatry and the Law | volume = 17 | issue = 2| pages = 153â163 | pmid = 2667656 }}</ref> (1989) theorized that either of the following situations could be antecedents to necrophilia (pp. 161):
#The necrophile develops poor [[self-esteem]], perhaps due in part to a significant loss;
#The necrophile develops poor [[self-esteem]], perhaps due in part to a significant loss;
#:(a) He/she is very fearful of rejection by women/men and he/she desires a sexual partner who is incapable of rejecting him/her; and/or
#:(a) He/she is very fearful of rejection by women/men and he/she desires a sexual partner who is incapable of rejecting him/her; and/or
